intro.p: Movie reviews help many people decide on whether or not they should go see a movie that they are interested in. With many movies coming out around the same time and the theater costing a fair amount of money, many people need to decide on one movie out of a few that they would like to go see. Movie reviews help out with this, and with the internet there are now more ways to find out if a movie is worth seeing or not. There are still written reviews, but now there are many people on websites such as YouTube who create video reviews for movies. The written review and the video review are both part of the same movie review genre, but they have a few key differences that separate them. Video reviews allow the viewer to see exactly how the reviewer feels about a movie while written reviews rely on just text to convey the reviewer’s feelings about a movie. One way to see these similarities and differences is to look at two reviews of the movie “Star Wars: The Force Awakens”, one written by Anthony Lane and a video created by Chris Stuckmann. “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” was a highly anticipated movie, so a lot of work went into the many reviews made about it.

body.bodyPara: Both the written movie review and the video movie review are a part of the movie review genre and the even larger review genre which exists because people enjoy sharing their opinions and others like to hear about those opinions to help them decide if they want the product or not. A movie review has one main goal, to help the reader decide if they want to see the reviewed movie or not. It does this by giving the reviewer’s personal opinion of the movie and then having the reviewer look at the movie objectively to tell the reader if it is a well made and well thought out movie or not. The review goes over the actors’ performances, the plot, the effects and other aspects found in all movies. Lane talks about how Daisy Ridley “straps herself in, swats aside any vestige of Mark Hamill, and takes command of the movie”(Lane). These reviews for “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” also compare the movie to its predecessors. For example, Anthony Lane compares a scene in the movie where a character uses the Force to pull a lightsaber towards them to the scene in “The Empire Strikes Back” when Luke Skywalker does the same thing (Lane). The movies are also compared in the video review. Stuckmann talks about how he loved the movie as much as the original “Star Wars” and more than “Return of the Jedi” (Stuckmann). All of this is what the written review and the video review have in common because they are part of the movie review genre.

While the written review and the video review both discuss the same topics, they do it in very different ways. In the video review, Stuckmann talks as if he is having a conversation with you. Since you can see him in the video, you see his facial expressions and can hear his tone of voice as he talks about the movie. It is easy to tell that he loved the movie and is excited to talk about it, even when he is talking about its flaws. Pictures also show up in the video to help show what he is talking about during the review (Stuckmann). With the written review, Lane needs to work harder to get his point across. He does not have luxury of his audience being able to hear and see him talk about the movie, so he need to be much more descriptive in what he says than Stuckmann needs to in the video review. This can be seen when he talks about Adam Driver’s performance. “So well is Driver cast against type here that evil may turn out to be his type, and so extraordinary are his features, long and quiveringly gaunt, that even when he removes his headpiece you still believe that you’re gazing at some form of advanced alien” (Lane). Another example is when Lane uses imagery to talk about how cinematic a scene in the movie was. “One battle, in particular, is a feast for the ears as well as the eyes, for it unfolds in a wintry forest. In addition to the usual throbbing hum of the weapons, (jazzed up a little for this movie, I fancy), you can hear the sizzle of sabre on snow, and the slicing hiss as the fighters miss their target and fell surrounding pine trees by mistake” (Lane). This shows how Lane must resort to using descriptive words and specially structured sentences to convey his feelings about the movie. He cannot just simply say he loved the movie, that the actors were phenomenal and that the director did a great job like Stuckmann can get away with in his video review. While Stuckmann just talks about how well actors performed and how great the film looked, Lane needs to describe what the actors did and exactly what the film looked like and how cinematic scenes were.

p.diff: The written review and the video review have big differences. The video review just tells the audience about the movie and how the reviewer feels about it while the written review describes how good the movie was to convey how the reviewer feels about it.
p.sim: But they still both have many similarities. They talk about the same topics and try to help their audience decide if they want to see the movie or not.
p.genre: Despite their differences, both the written review and the video review fit clearly in the movie review genre.
